qas.question: What was Tuscon known as 12,000 years ago?

Near what river was a village site dating from 2100 BC found?
Who were probably the first group of people in Tuscan?

answers.text: the first extensive use of pottery vessels for cooking and storage

qas.question: When did the Hohokam live in the Tucson area?

context: Tucson was probably first visited by <a3_0>Paleo-Indians<a3_0/>, known to have been in <a0_0>southern Arizona<a0_0/> <a5_0>about <a4_0>12,000 years ago<a5_0/><a4_0/>. Recent archaeological excavations near the <a2_0>Santa Cruz River<a2_0/> have located a village site dating from <a6_0>2100 BC<a6_0/>.[citation needed] The floodplain of the Santa Cruz River was extensively farmed during the Early Agricultural period, circa <a7_0>1200 BC to AD 150<a7_0/>. These people constructed irrigation canals and grew corn, beans, and other crops while gathering wild plants and hunting. The Early Ceramic period occupation of Tucson saw <a8_0>the first extensive use of pottery vessels for cooking and storage<a8_0/>. The groups designated as the <a1_0>Hohokam<a1_0/> lived in the area <a9_0>from AD 600 to 1450<a9_0/> and are known for their vast irrigation canal systems and their red-on-brown pottery.[citation needed]
